thread.title: Private equity firm Kimmeridge Energy boosts Carrizo stake, urges asset sales

title: Private equity firm Kimmeridge Energy boosts Carrizo stake, urges asset sales
text:
HOUSTON/NEW YORK (Reuters) - Kimmeridge Energy Management Co has boosted its stake in Carrizo Oil & Gas Inc ( CRZO.O ) by more than 65 percent and wants the U.S. shale producer to sell assets or combine with a rival to boost its share price, the private equity firm said on Thursday.
Investors have grown increasingly fed up with the U.S. shale industry’s spendthrift ways and are pushing producers to improve shareholder returns and focus less on output.
“Our goal is essentially to put management on notice that we believe they have to do something” within a year, Ben Dell, managing director of Kimmeridge, said in an interview.
Jeff Hayden, Carrizo’s head of investor relations, declined to comment when reached in person at the company’s Houston headquarters.
Shares of Carrizo were up more than 12 percent at $17.34 in midday trading. Up until Wednesday’s close, the stock had lost about half its value in the past year despite a rise in crude oil prices CLc1.
New York-based Kimmeridge now owns or controls about 8.1 percent of Carrizo’s float, roughly 6.6 million shares, according to a regulatory filing. The firm, which is now the company’s fourth-largest shareholder, previously held about 4.9 percent of shares, according to Thomson Reuters data.
Carrizo should sell its Eagle Ford shale acreage in East Texas to cull debt and focus entirely on its operations in the Permian Basin, the largest U.S. oilfield, Kimmeridge said.
“If management wanted us to run the company, we’d be happy to do that, too,” Dell said, noting Kimmeridge has held Permian acreage in the past and is comfortable operating oil assets.
“We are not your classical New York activist hedge fund with a short duration model.”
Kimmeridge said Carrizo should also consider a stock buyback or a merger with a Permian rival. Concho Resources Inc ( CXO.N ) last week said it would combine with Permian rival RSP Permian Inc ( RSPP.N ) in an $8 billion all-stock deal.
Kimmeridge said in the filing that it was concerned about Carrizo’s debt, up 80 percent in the past five years at $1.63 billion, more than the company’s market valuation.
Carrizo lost $17 million in the fourth quarter of 2017 even as its production jumped 13 percent to 62,417 barrels of oil equivalent.
Additional reporting by David French in New York; Editing by Bernadette Baum and Susan Thomas
